conclusion: Use given information and thermodynamics principles to calculate heat exchanged.
State A: pressure 1.0 × 10^5 Pa, volume 1.0 × 10^-3 m^3; State C: pressure 3.0 × 10^5 Pa, volume 4.0 × 10^-3 m^3.
Internal energy change from state A to C is 200 J.
Temperature at state A is -73°C, equivalent to 25°C; at state C, temperature is 300 K.
Volume change from state A to C is an increase of 3.0 × 10^-3 m^3.
Apply first law of thermodynamics: Q = m ⋅ ΔU - n ⋅ R ⋅ ΔT.
Since mass is constant, use formula Q = m ⋅ ΔU.
Heat Q exchanged equals change in internal energy, 200 J.
Calculate moles using ideal gas law: m = N_A ⋅ V / R.
Substitute into heat Q equation: Q = 0.122 mol ⋅ 200 J = 24.4 J.
Discrepancy arises from moles calculation; correct calculation: Q = 24.4 J.
Re-evaluate heat Q using ideal gas law: Q = m ⋅ ΔU = 24.4 J.
